channel.title: James Leslie's Blog
channel.description: This feed provides my blog posts!

item.title: Stoicism and raising a puppy
item.description:
Posted on June 8, 2021 by James Leslie

A month or two ago, my girlfriend, her brother and I went for a drive and came back with a puppy. My girlfriend had been wanting a puppy for many years; now that the day had come where she would get to take one home, she was beaming more than ever. When I lived in Scotland, my family raised and loved a yellow labrador (named Bobby), so I knew what to expect from the coming months. Or so I thought. Bobby came into my life when I was a mere 10 years old, so most of my memories of him are from the later stages in his life. My parentsâ€™ memories of this time will probably be better than mine. I have the occasional memory of Bobby chewing on the skirting boards and urinating behind the sofa, but apart from that, he is a dream dog in my mind.

The new puppy (Woody) makes me doubt the integrity of my previous memories. Woody is a chocolate labrador, with an apt name. Anything in our vicinity made of wood will end up suffering the misfortune of being chewed on. The list of casualties includes chairs, desks, tables, skirting boards, book shelves, notebooks and, of course, twigs and branches. This is only the list of his wooden feasts. Woody also has a real taste for plastic and metal, which unfortunately we found out when he chewed his way through my girlfriendâ€™s bikeâ€™s chain guard.

This brings me to my first reflection on Stoicism. Keeping a puppy that tries to destroy everything in reach reminded me of the temporary nature of belongings. It is far too easy to forget that even though we purchase items, they donâ€™t last forever. Even if they do out last us, we donâ€™t take them with us. We should appreciate what we have while we have it.

My second reflection is about anger. Before Woody came into my life, I thought that I was very hard to anger: I canâ€™t remember a recent time that felt really angry. Now though, it seems like every day my anger rises to the surface. This usually happens when Woody thinks itâ€™s a good idea to go around trying to eat everything in the house, including computer cables. When this happens, I have a real desire to punish Woody, but really this is only anger trying to take control. Punishment in the form of yelling or hitting serves no good, even in trying to get Woodyâ€™s behaviour to change. Some say that it can even reinforce the behaviour. The only reason I have a desire to punish him is because of the anger that bubbles up. The only purpose it serves is as a release for me. I need to accept that chewing is a part of his nature, especially now that he is teething. The best thing to do is to try and redirect his attention to one of his many toys, designed for withstanding his mighty chomp. When he canâ€™t be redirected, itâ€™s time for him to sleep.

When my girlfriend and I were planning living with a new dog, I didnâ€™t think that Stoic values would be an important factor in raising it. I am glad that I was wrong.

Attached is a picture of the (not so little) Woody. Today, he has been a real star of a puppy and as I type this, he is fast asleep in his bed.
item.dc:creator: James Leslie

item.title: The Canonical Model Structure on Cat/Gpd
item.description:
Posted on March 6, 2021 by James Leslie

When one first starts studying category theory, they learn that the correct notion of â€œthe sameâ€ for categories is that of equivalence, rather than the stronger notion isomorphism. For those that have studied some algebraic topology, the situation is very similar to identifying spaces if they are homotopic, rather than homeomorphic. This is often given as an analogy, but the two notions can be reconciled by giving model structures where the weaker form of identification forms the subcategory of weak equivalences. Here, we define and present the so called canonical model structure on the category of categories. The proof of each step given can also be applied to the category of groupoids.

We denote the category of (small) categories by ğ‚ğšğ­\mathbf{Cat} and the category of (small) groupoids ğ†ğ©ğ\mathbf{Gpd}.

This proof can be found on the nLabâ€™s â€œcanonical model structure on Catâ€ page, but here we go into a lot more detail of the constructions.

The model structure

Let CC be a category and (A,B)(A, B) a pair of subcategories. The pair (A,B)(A, B) is a weak factorisation system if:

  1. Both AA and BB are stable under retracts;
  2. AA is in the left lifting class of BB (AâŠ‚LBA \subset LB);
  3. Every morphism f:Xâ†’Yf : X \to Y in CC factors as f=pif = pi with iâˆˆAi \in A and pâˆˆBp \in B.

A model structure on a category ğ’\mathcal{C} consists of a triple of wide subcategories W,F,CW, F, C whose morphisms are called weak equivalences (anotated with a âˆ¼\sim), fibrations (annotated with a double head â† \twoheadrightarrow) and cofibrations (annotated with a tail â†£\rightarrowtail), respectively. This triple must satisfy the following three axioms:

  1. WW satisfies 2-out-of-3;
  2. (F,Wâˆ©C)(F, W \cap C) is a weak factorisation system;
  3. (Fâˆ©W,C)(F \cap W, C) is a weak factorisation system.

A model category is a finitely bicomplete category, along with a model structure on it.

Before giving the main result, we need one more definition.

Let F:ğ’œâ†’â„¬F: \mathcal{A} \to \mathcal{B} be a functor. We say FF is an isofibration if for every aâˆˆğ’œa \in \mathcal{A} and isomorphism f:Faâ†’bâˆˆâ„¬f : Fa \to b \in \mathcal{B}, there is an isomorphism g:aâ†’aâ€²âˆˆğ’œg: a \to a' \in \mathcal{A} such that Ff=gFf = g.

Our main result is the following:

The category ğ‚ğšğ­\mathbf{Cat} has a model structure on it with:

  1. WW being the class of categorical equivalences;
  2. FF being the class of isofibrations;
  3. CC being the class of functors injective on objects.

The rest of this section will be proving the above theorem. That ğ‚ğšğ­\mathbf{Cat} and ğ†ğ©ğ\mathbf{Gpd} has all finite limits follows from it having a terminal object, binary products and equalisers. The theory of categories and groupoids are generalised algebraic theories, so the category of models (ğ‚ğšğ­\mathbf{Cat} and ğ†ğ©ğ\mathbf{Gpd}, respectively) has all (finite) colimits.

We now break down each of the defining features of a model structure and show that they hold here.

2-out-of-3

Categorical equivalences are closed under 2-out-of-3.

This follows by basic diagram chasing. If we have the following commuting triangle, with any two maps being equivalences, we can take pseudo-inverses to construct a pseudo-inverse to the third map.

Retracts

The class of categorical equivalences is stable under retracts.

Suppose we have the following commuting diagram where gg is an equivalence. We show ff is also an equivalence:

Since gg is an equivalence, there exists a functor gâ€²g' such that ggâ€²â‰…1Vgg' \cong 1_V and gâ€²gâ‰…1Ug'g \cong 1_U. The morphism pgâ€²jpg'j is then easily seen to be a pseudo-inverse to ff, showing that it is also an equivalence.

The class of isofibrations is stable under retracts.

Suppose the following diagram commutes and gg is an isofibration. We need to show that ff is an isofibration also:

Let xâˆˆXx \in X and Î±:fxâ†’y\alpha : fx \to y be an isomorphism in YY. We apply jj to get an isomorphism jÎ±:jfx=gixâ†’jyj\alpha : jfx=gix \to jy. As gg is an isofibration, there is an isomorphism Î²:ixâ†’uâˆˆU\beta : ix \to u \in U such that gÎ²=jÎ±g\beta = j\alpha. Applying pp, we have an isomorphism pÎ²:pix=xâ†’puâˆˆXp\beta : pix=x \to pu \in X. If we apply ff to this map, we have:

Hence, given an isomorphism Î±\alpha, there exists an isomorphism pÎ²p\beta such that fpÎ²=Î±fp\beta = \alpha, so ff is also an isofibration.

The class of functors injective on objects is stable under retracts.

Suppose we have the following diagram in ğ‚ğšğ­\mathbf{Cat}, where gg is a functor injective on objects. We need to show that ff is injective on objects also:

Suppose xx and yy are objects in XX such that fx=fyfx = fy. We have the following chain of equalities:

Hence ff is also injective on objects.

Lifting properties

We first give a lemma that will be useful in solving the lifting problems in this section.

Isofibrations that are equivalences are exactly the equivalences that are surjective on objects.

Suppose that F:ğ’œâ†’â„¬F: \mathcal{A} \to \mathcal{B} is an isofibration and an equivalence. To see that it is surjective on objects, let bâˆˆBb \in B. As FF is an equivalence, it is fully faithful, so there is some aâˆˆğ’œa \in \mathcal{A} and isomorphism Î²:Faâ†’bâˆˆâ„¬\beta : Fa \to b \in \mathcal{B}. As FF is an isofibration, there is an isomorphism Î±:aâ†’aâ€²âˆˆğ’œ\alpha : a \to a' \in \mathcal{A} such that FÎ±=Î²F\alpha = \beta. Then, we must have that Faâ€²=bFa' = b, so FF is surjective on objects.

If FF is an equivalence that is surjective on objects, it is also an isofibration. Let aâˆˆğ’œa \in \mathcal{A} and Î²:Faâ†’b\beta : Fa \to b be an isomorphism in â„¬\mathcal{B}. As FF is surjective on objects, b=Faâ€²b = Fa' for some aâ€²âˆˆğ’œa' \in \mathcal{A}, so Î²\beta is a map Faâ†’Faâ€²Fa \to Fa'. By FF being full, there is a morphism Î±:aâ†’aâ€²\alpha : a \to a' such that FÎ±=Î²F\alpha = \beta. By FF being faithful, this Î±\alpha must be an isomorphism, so FF is an isofibration.

The class of functors injective on objects has the left lifting property with respect to functors that are isofibrations and equivalences.

Suppose we have the following commuting diagram, where ff is injective on objects and gg is an equivalence and isofibration:

As this commutes, we have the following ``object squareâ€™â€™ commuting in ğ’ğğ­\mathbf{Set}:

In particular, f0f_0 is injective and by Lemma 10, g0g_0 is surjective. As (inj,surj)(\text{inj}, \text{surj}) form a weak factorisation system on ğ’ğğ­\mathbf{Set}, there is a lift h0h_0. We now aim to turn h0h_0 into a functor. Let Î±:yâ†’yâ€²\alpha: y \to y' be a morphism in YY. We then have a morphism jÎ±:jy=gh0yâ†’gh0yâ€²=jyâ€²âˆˆV0j\alpha : jy = gh_0y \to gh_0y'=jy' \in V_0. As gg is fully faithful, there is a unique morphism Î²:h0yâ†’h0yâ€²âˆˆU\beta : h_0 y \to h_0 y' \in U such that gÎ²=jÎ±g\beta = j\alpha. We define hÎ±:=Î²h\alpha := \beta. As jj is a functor, it must preserve identity morphisms and as gg is fully faithful, the lift of an identity morphism from vv to uu must be the identity, so hh preserves identity morphisms. Similarly, by functorality of jj and fully faithfulness of gg, we have that composites are mapped to composites, so hh is a functor and makes the bottom triangle commute:

The top triangle commutes on objects, so we need to check it commutes on maps. Given Î±:xâ†’xâ€²âˆˆX\alpha : x \to x' \in X,

So iÎ±=hfÎ±i \alpha = h f \alpha by fully faithfulness of gg, meaning that the top triangle commutes. This means that hh is indeed a lift, which shows that functors injective on objects are in the left lifting class of fucntors that are equivalences and isofibrations.

The class of functors injective on objects which are also equivalences has the left lifting property with respect to functors that are isofibrations.

Suppose we have the following diagram commuting, with ff an equivalence that is injective on objects and gg an isofibration:

To construct a functor h:Yâ†’Uh:Y \to U, we use the axiom of choice to get some extra structure. As ff is essentially surjective, for every object yâˆˆYy \in Y, we choose an isomorphism Î±y:fxyâ†’y\alpha_y : fx_y \to y, picking the identity morphism wherever possible, i.e Î±fx=1fx\alpha_{fx} = 1_{fx} (we call the argument of ff xyx_y, which is well defined at ff is injective on objects). As gg is an isofibration, we choose for every yâˆˆYy \in Y a morphism Î²y:ixyâ†’uyâˆˆU\beta_y : ix_y \to u_y \in U such that gÎ²y=jÎ±yg\beta_y = j\alpha_y, again, picking the identity morphism whenever possible, i.e Î²fx=1ix\beta_{fx} = 1_{ix}. On objects, we define h(y)=uyh(y) = u_y. For morphisms, the output is a little more complicated. Starting with a map Î³:yâ†’yâ€²\gamma : y \to y', we form the composite Î±yâ€²âˆ’1Î³Î±y:fxyâ†’fxyâ€²\alpha_{y'}^{-1} \gamma \alpha_y : fx_y \to fx_{y'}. We let Î±yâ€²âˆ’1Î³Î±yÂ¯:xyâ†’xyâ€²\overline{\alpha_{y'}^{-1} \gamma \alpha_y} : x_y \to x_{y'} be the unique map that ff maps to Î±yâ€²âˆ’1Î³Î±y\alpha_{y'}^{-1} \gamma \alpha_y. Then, applying ii, we have a map iÎ±yâ€²âˆ’1Î³Î±yÂ¯:ixyâ†’ixyâ€²i \overline{\alpha_{y'}^{-1} \gamma \alpha_y} : ix_y \to ix_{y'}. We can then compose with maps Î²yâˆ’1\beta_y^{-1} and Î²yâ€²\beta_{y'} to get Î²yâ€²i(Î±yâ€²âˆ’1Î³Î±yÂ¯)Î²yâˆ’1:uyâ†’uyâ€²\beta_{y'} i \left(\overline{\alpha_{y'}^{-1} \gamma \alpha_y}\right) \beta_{y}^{-1} : u_y \to u_{y'}. This is what we define hÎ³h\gamma to be.

To see that hh is a functor, we see that it sends the identity to the identity:

We also see that hh preserves composites: let Î³:yâ†’yâ€²\gamma : y \to y' and Î´:yâ€²â†’yâ€³\delta : y' \to y''. Then:

We now show that it makes both the triangles commute:

Given xâˆˆXx \in X, we need ix=ufxix = u_{fx}, however this follows from our choice of maps being the identity wherever possible, which means Î²fx=1ix\beta_{fx} = 1_{ix}. Likewise, for maps Î³:xâ†’xâ€²\gamma: x \to x', our chosen isomorphisms are the identity, giving hfÎ³=iÎ³hf\gamma = i\gamma. Now, if yâˆˆYy \in Y, we see by definition that guy=jygu_y = jy, so the bottom triangle commutes on objects. Given a map Î³:yâ†’yâ€²âˆˆY\gamma : y \to y' \in Y, by the properties of Î²y\beta_y we have:

Hence hh is a lift, as required.

Factorisations

Every functor can be factored as a functor injective on objects, followed by a functor that is an isofibration and equivalence.

Given f:Xâ†’Yf:X \to Y, we form a new category ZZ with objects given by X0âˆY0X_0 \coprod Y_0. We define the hom-sets as follows:

We then have a functor Xâ†’ZX \to Z which is the identity on objects, and ff on maps, which, in particular, is injective on objects. We can also construct another functor Zâ†’YZ \to Y which is formed by applying ff to objects from XX and the identity to objects from yy. It is then the identity morphism on maps, which means it is fully faithful. It is also surjective on objects as every object in YY is mapped to itself by this functor. The composite of these two morphisms is ff on objects and ff on maps, hence it is a factorisation of ff into a functor injective on objects, followed by a surjective equivalence (which by Lemma 10) is an equivalence and isofibration), as required.

Every functor can be factored as a functor injective on objects and an equivalence, followed by an isofibration.

Given f:Xâ†’Yf:X \to Y we form the comma category Fâ†“1YF \downarrow 1_Y, then take the full subcategory spanned by objects (x,y,Ï•:fxâ†’y)(x, y, \phi : fx \to y) where Ï•\phi is an isomorphism in YY. Denote this category as Fâ†“â‰…1YF \downarrow_{\cong} 1_Y Note that we have a functor Xâ†’Fâ†“â‰…1YX \to F \downarrow_{\cong} 1_Y defined by sending xâ†¦(x,fx,1fx)x \mapsto (x , fx, 1_{fx}) and Î±:xâ†’xâ€²â†¦(Î±,fÎ±)\alpha : x \to x' \mapsto (\alpha, f\alpha). This is clearly injective on objects and fully faithful. We also have that every (x,y,Ï•)â‰…(x,fx,1fx)(x, y, \phi) \cong (x, fx, 1_{fx}) by the following commuting square in YY (with horizontal maps being isomorphisms):

We have a functor fâ†“â‰…1Yâ†’Yf \downarrow_{\cong} 1_Y \to Y given by projecting out the second component. This functor is also seen to be an isofibration: given (x,y,Ï•)(x, y, \phi) and an isomorphism Î±:yâ†’yâ€²âˆˆY\alpha : y \to y' \in Y, the following square commutes, with horizontal maps isomorphisms, so is an isomorphism in fâ†“â‰…1Yf \downarrow_{\cong} 1_Y:

Our projection functor sends this isomorphism to Î±\alpha, so it is an isofibration. The composite of the two functors defined is easily seen to be equal to ff, completing the factorisation of ff as an equivalence that is injective on objects, followed by an isofibration.

Putting it all together

Functors injective on objects and equivalences that are isofibrations, form a weak factorisation system on ğ‚ğšğ­\mathbf{Cat}.

Lemma 9 shows functors injective on objects are stable under retracts. Lemmas 9 and 9 show that equivalences that are isofibrations are also stable under retracts. Lemma 13 gives the desired lifting data and Lemma 14 gives the desired factorisation.

Equivalences that are injective on objects and isofibrations form a weak factorisation system on ğ‚ğšğ­\mathbf{Cat}.

Lemmas 7 and 9 show that the class of equivalences that are injective on objects is stable under retracts. Lemma 8 shows the class of isofibrations are stable under retracts. Lemma 12 gives the desired lifting data and Lemma 14 gives the desired factorisation.

The category ğ‚ğšğ­\mathbf{Cat} has a model structure on it with:

  1. WW being the class of equivalences;
  2. FF being the class of isofibrations;
  3. CC being the class of functors injective on objects.

Lemma shows that WW satisfies 2-out-of-3. Corollaries 15 and 16 show that (Câˆ©W,F)(C \cap W, F) and (C,Fâˆ©W)(C, F \cap W) are weak factorisation systems.

This proves Theorem 5. To see that this restricts to ğ†ğ©ğ\mathbf{Gpd} we only need to realise that if XX and YY are groupoids, the categories constructed in the Factorisations section are also groupoids. This means we have the following:

The category ğ†ğ©ğ\mathbf{Gpd} has a model structure on it with:

  1. WW being the class of categorical equivalences;
  2. FF being the class of isofibrations;
  3. CC being the class of functors injective on objects.
item.dc:creator: James Leslie

item.title: iPad Screen Sharing to Zoom on a University Network
item.description:
Posted on March 5, 2021 by James Leslie

I am currently a teaching assistant for a first year linear algebra course. We recently made the switch to a hybrid setup, meaning that I am streaming the tutorials on Zoom as well as talking to a class in-person. Instead of writing on the physical whiteboards in the classroom, I instead write on my iPad and share the screen through Zoom. Previously, when the tutorials were just based on Zoom, this setup worked pretty well - I can share my screen over Zoom using my home WiFi network. However, I canâ€™t screen share over the university network due to the way it is set up.

Solution 1

The basic solution is to log into the Zoom call on the iPad, and share the screen through the Zoom app. This is less than ideal, however; as it means that if you havenâ€™t turned off notifications, they can be displayed to the class. Also, I use the app GoodNotes to write my solutions on. The app is good, but there is a large header of different pen options that takes up too much space for my liking. This header is not shown when sharing content to Zoom over the network, rather than through the IPad.

Solution 2

The current solution I use works on Windows 10 laptops. Windows 10 has the functionality to be connected to a network whilst also being a WiFi hotspot. Information on how to enable this can be found here. Once the hotspot is up and running, we can connect the iPad to the network. Then, Zoom can detect the IPad, and we can share content over this network. So far, this has worked well for me. The only caveat is that it seems like you canâ€™t get access to the internet on the IPad whilst connected to the network. This isnâ€™t a major problem for me, as I still have access through my laptop.

This setup might work for other operating systems, but I am not able to test that theory out.
item.dc:creator: James Leslie

item.title: A group object in the category of groups
item.dc:creator: James Leslie

item.title: Why isn't every category isomorphic to its opposite?
item.description:
Posted on July 7, 2018 by James Leslie

Whenever one comes across a mathematical object, such as a group, topological space etc, it is important to look at how it interacts with other similar objects. The same goes for categories with functors being how they interact.

Given two categories ğ’œ,â„¬ \mathscr{A}, \mathscr{B}, a (covariant) functor F F from ğ’œ \mathscr{A} to â„¬ \mathscr{B} assigns to each object Aâˆˆğ’œ A \in \mathscr{A} an object F(A)âˆˆâ„¬ F(A) \in \mathscr{B} and to each ğ’œ \mathscr{A}-morphism f:Aâ†’Aâ€² f:A \rightarrow A', a â„¬ \mathscr{B}-morphism F(f):F(A)â†’F(Aâ€²) F(f):F(A) \rightarrow F(A'). The assignements must respect composition and identities, so

  • F(gâˆ˜h)=F(g)âˆ˜F(h) F(g \circ h) = F(g) \circ F(h), for ğ’œ \mathscr{A}-maps f,g f,g,
  • F(1A)=1F(A) F(1_A) = 1_{F(A)}, for all Aâˆˆğ’œ A \in \mathscr{A}.

We write functors as F:ğ’œâ†’â„¬ F: \mathscr{A} \rightarrow \mathscr{B}. This then leads to the category ğ‚ğ€ğ“ \mathbf{CAT} whose objects are categories and whose morphisms are functors. We say that two categories are isomorphic if they are isomorphic in ğ‚ğ€ğ“ \mathbf{CAT}. Given a category ğ’œ \mathscr{A}, we can form its opposite category ğ’œop \mathscr{A}^{op}, whose objects are the same as those in ğ’œ \mathscr{A}, with ğ’œop \mathscr{A}^{op}-morphisms f:Aâ€²â†’A f:A' \rightarrow A in one to one correspondence with ğ’œ \mathscr{A}-morphisms f:Aâ†’Aâ€² f:A \rightarrow A'. This means we can think of ğ’œop \mathscr{A}^{op} as being ğ’œ \mathscr{A} with itâ€™s morphisms turned around. It is clear from the definition of a functor that the obvious correspondence between a category and its opposite is not a functor. However, we can define a new type of functor that makes this possible.

A contravariant functor F F from ğ’œ \mathscr{A} to â„¬ \mathscr{B} is a (covariant) functor F:ğ’œopâ†’â„¬ F:\mathscr{A}^{op} \rightarrow \mathscr{B}.

The key property of a contravariant functor is that it reverses composition. If F F from ğ’œ \mathscr{A} to â„¬ \mathscr{B} is a contravariant functor, then for ğ’œ \mathscr{A}-morphisms f,g f, g, we have F(fâˆ˜g)=F(g)âˆ˜F(f) F(f \circ g) = F(g) \circ F(f).

A question one may ask is whether or not a category is isomorphic to its opposite. In general this is false; however, to newcomers this isnâ€™t always obvious why. A typical false proof goes along the following lines:

  1. For any category ğ’œ \mathscr{A}, there are canonical contravariant functors F:ğ’œopâ†’ğ’œ F:\mathscr{A}^{op} \rightarrow \mathscr{A} and G:ğ’œâ†’ğ’œop G:\mathscr{A} \rightarrow \mathscr{A}^{op}.
  2. Clearly Fâˆ˜G=1ğ’œ F\circ G= 1_{\mathscr{A}} and Gâˆ˜F=1ğ’œop G\circ F= 1_{\mathscr{A}^{op}}.
  3. ğ’œâ‰…ğ’œop \mathscr{A} \cong \mathscr{A}^{op}.

The reason this doesnâ€™t hold is because the functors defined are contravariant, not covariant. To show such an isomorphism exists, one would need to construct a covariant functor F:ğ’œopâ†’ğ’œ F:\mathscr{A}^{op} \rightarrow \mathscr{A}, so in particular the composition rule in Definition 1 must hold. Clearly for an arbitrary category, the canonical (contravariant) functor breaks this rule. A counter-example is to have a category with a terminal object and but no initial object. Its opposite has an initial object but no terminal, hence the two arenâ€™t isomorphic.

Take the following two categories ğ’œ\mathcal A and â„¬\mathcal B, where â„¬=ğ’œop\mathcal B = \mathcal A ^{\text{op}}.

Suppose we have a covariant functor from ğ’œâ†’â„¬\mathcal A \rightarrow \mathcal B that fixes the objects. The issue is that there are no arrows in â„¬\mathcal B that we can map ff or gg to. Since such a functor doesnâ€™t exist, ğ’œ\mathcal A and â„¬\mathcal B cannot be isomorphic. For such a functor to exist, it must be contravariant.
item.dc:creator: James Leslie

item.title: Categories of elements
item.description:
Posted on June 30, 2018 by James Leslie

When learning about colimits and presheaf categories, one often meets a category of elements. The definition of the category isnâ€™t particularly hard to understand or remember; however, I didnâ€™t immediately have an intuition for why it is useful or where the definition came from. This has lead me to play with it and try to understand some properties of it.

Given a locally small category ğ”¸ \mathbb{A} and a functor X:ğ”¸opâ†’ğ’ğğ­ X:\mathbb{A}^{op} \rightarrow \mathbf{Set}, the category of elementsÂ of X X, denoted ğ”¼(X) \mathbb{E}(X) or âˆ«ğ”¸X \int^\mathbb{A} X, is defined as follows:

  • Objects are pairs (Aâˆˆğ”¸,xâˆˆX(A)) (A \in \mathbb{A}, x \in X(A)),
  • Morphisms f:(A,x)â†’(Aâ€²,xâ€²) f:(A, x) \rightarrow (A',x') are maps f:Aâ†’Aâ€²âˆˆğ”¸ f:A \rightarrow A' \in \mathbb{A} such that (Xf)(xâ€²)=x (Xf)(x')=x.

Every category of elements has a projection functor P:ğ”¼(x)â†’ğ”¸ P:\mathbb{E}(x) \rightarrow \mathbb{A} associated with it that sends (A,x)â†¦A (A,x) \mapsto A and fâ†¦f f \mapsto f. There is a useful property tucked away in the definition: for any ğ”¸ \mathbb{A}-arrowÂ f:Aâ€²â†’A f:A' \rightarrow A, there is a unique element xâ€²âˆˆX(Aâ€²) x' \in X(A') such that there is an ğ”¼(X) \mathbb{E}(X)-morphism f:(Aâ€²,xâ€²)â†’(A,x) f:(A',x') \rightarrow (A, x), namely xâ€²=(Xf)(x) x' = (Xf)(x). As a result of this, we will often write morphism as f:(Aâ€²,(Xf)(x))â†’(A,x) f:(A', (Xf)(x)) \rightarrow (A,x). Another observation is that we can write ğ”¼(X) \mathbb{E}(X) as a comma category.

There is an isomorphism ğ”¼(X)â‰…(1â‡’X) \mathbb{E}(X) \cong (1 \Rightarrow X).

We look at the comma category for the following diagram:

The double stroke 1 is the terminal category and the functor 1 is the functor that selects the terminal set. This category has as objects, pairs (Aâˆˆğ”¸,x:1â†’X(A)) (A \in \mathbb{A}, x:1 \rightarrow X(A)) and morphisms f:(A,x)â†’(Aâ€²,xâ€²) f:(A,x) \rightarrow (A',x') are commuting triangles:

That this triangle commutes is the same as stating x=(Xf)(xâ€²) x = (Xf)(x'), which is the condition above.

We can use the category of elements to relate representablity to the existence of a terminal object.

[1, Exercise 6.2.23] Let X X be a presheaf on a locally small category. X X is representable if and only if ğ”¼(X) \mathbb{E}(X) has a terminal object.

The category ğ”¼(X) \mathbb{E}(X) has a terminal object if and only if there is an object (A,x) (A, x) such that for any (Aâ€²,xâ€²) (A',x'), there is exactly one morphism f:(Aâ€²,xâ€²)â†’(A,x) f:(A',x') \rightarrow (A,x). This is equivalent to there being an Aâˆˆğ”¸ A \in \mathbb{A} and xâˆˆX(A) x \in X(A) such that for all Aâ€²âˆˆğ”¸ A' \in \mathbb{A}, xâˆˆX(Aâ€²) x \in X(A'), there is a unique morphism f:Aâ€²â†’A f:A' \rightarrow A such that (Xf)(x)=xâ€² (Xf)(x) = x'. This condition is equivalent to X X being representable, by [Corollary 4.3.2, 1].

One of the most important uses of the category of elements is to show that any presheaf is a colimit of a certain diagram, in a canonical way. This is the main purpose of the category of elements in [1, Definition 6.2.16].

[1, Theorem 6.2.17] Let ğ”¸ \mathbb{A} be small and X:ğ”¸opâ†’ğ’ğğ­ X:\mathbb{A}^{op} \rightarrow \mathbf{Set} a presheaf. Then X X is the colimit of the following diagram:

That is, Xâ‰…limâ†’ğ”¼(X)(Hâ€¢âˆ˜P) X \cong \lim{\rightarrow \mathbb{E}(X)}(H\bullet \circ P).

We should first note that this does make sense; as ğ”¸ \mathbb{A} is small, so is ğ”¼(X) \mathbb{E}(X), hence a colimit does indeed exist.

We know that presheaf categories have all (small) limits and colimits, so a colimit of Hâ€¢âˆ˜P H_\bullet \circ P exists. Let Yâˆˆ[ğ”¸op,ğ’ğğ­] Y \in [\mathbb{A}^{op}, \mathbf{Set}] be a presheaf and let (Î±(A,x):(Hâ€¢âˆ˜P)(A,x)â†’Y)(A,x)âˆˆğ”¼(X) (\alpha_{(A,x)}:(H_\bullet \circ P)(A,x) \rightarrow Y)_{(A,x)\in \mathbb{E}(X)} be a cocone on Hâ€¢âˆ˜P H_\bullet \circ P with vertex Y Y. We can simply this to have (Î±(A,x):(HAâ†’Y)(A,x)âˆˆğ”¼(X) (\alpha_{(A,x)}:(H_A \rightarrow Y)_{(A,x)\in \mathbb{E}(X)}. This is a family of natural transformations, so for all f:(Aâ€²,xâ€²)â†’(A,x) f:(A',x') \rightarrow (A, x) in ğ”¼(X) \mathbb{E}(X), the folowing diagram commutes

By the Yoneda lemma, every natural transformation Î±(A,x):HAâ†’Y \alpha_{(A,x)}:H_A \rightarrow Y corresponds to a unique element (Î±(A,x))A(1A)âˆˆY(A) (\alpha_{(A,x)})_A(1_A) \in Y(A), which we shall denote y(A,x) y_{(A,x)}. As the diagram above commutes, it commutes for all Aâˆˆğ”¸ A \in \mathbb{A}, so in particular it commutes for Aâ€² A'. This gives us the following:

This gives us y(Aâ€²,(Xf)(x))=(Î±(A,x))Aâ€²(f) y_{(A',(Xf)(x))} = (\alpha_{(A,x)})_{A'}(f). As Î±(A,x) \alpha_{(A,x)} is a natural transformation, the following square commutes:

This gives us (Yf)(y(A,x))=(Î±(A,x))Aâ€²(f) (Yf)(y_{(A,x)}) = (\alpha_{(A,x)})_{A'}(f). Combining this with the above we see that a cocone on Y Y is a collection of elements (y(A,x))(A,x)âˆˆğ”¼(X) (y_{(A,x)})_{(A,x)\in \mathbb{E}(X)} such that for any f:(Aâ€²,(Xf)(x))â†’(A,x) f:(A',(Xf)(x)) \rightarrow (A,x) in ğ”¼(X) \mathbb{E}(X), (Yf)(y(A,x))=y(Aâ€²,(Xf)(x)) (Yf)(y_{(A,x)}) = y_{(A', (Xf)(x))}.

An equivalent way to write y(A,x) y_{(A,x)} is Î±Â¯A(x):X(A)â†’Y(A) \overline{\alpha}_A(x):X(A) \rightarrow Y(A) and treat it as a function.The properties above then say for any f:(Aâ€²,(Xf)(x))â†’(A,x) f:(A', (Xf)(x)) \rightarrow (A,x) in ğ”¼(X) \mathbb{E}(X), (Yf)(Î±Â¯A(x))=Î±Â¯Aâ€²((Xf)(x)) (Yf)(\overline{\alpha}_A(x)) = \overline{\alpha}_{A'}((Xf)(x)), that is to say the following diagram commutes for all f:Aâ€²â†’A f:A' \rightarrow A in ğ”¸ \mathbb{A}:

This shows that Î±Â¯:Xâ†’Y \overline{\alpha}:X \rightarrow Y is a natural transformation. As all of the above is equivalent, we see that a cocone on Y Y is the same as a map from X X into Y Y, hence X X is the colimit of Hâ€¢âˆ˜P H_\bullet \circ P. We can write this as equivalence formally as

[ğ”¼(X),[ğ”¸op,ğ’ğğ­]](Hâ€¢âˆ˜P,Î”Y)â‰…[ğ”¸op,ğ’ğğ­](X,Y) [\mathbb{E}(X), [\mathbb{A}^{op}, \mathbf{Set}]](H_\bullet \circ P, \Delta Y) \cong [\mathbb{A}^{op}, \mathbf{Set}](X,Y).

This is an application of the dual of [Equation 6.2, 1].

The property that morphisms in ğ”¼(X) \mathbb{E}(X) have is vital to this proof and, to myself atleast, shows why we need to use this particular small category.

Given a set S S, there is an equivalence of categories ğ’ğğ­/Sâ‰ƒğ’ğğ­S \mathbf{Set}/S \simeq \mathbf{Set}^S, where the latter has as objects S S indexed tuples of sets. Given (A,f:Aâ†’S)âˆˆğ’ğğ­/S (A, f:A \rightarrow S) \in \mathbf{Set}/S, we form the tuple (fâˆ’1(s))sâˆˆS (f^{-1}(s))_{s \in S} and given a tuple (As)sâˆˆS (A_s)_{s \in S}, we form the disjoint union âˆsâˆˆSAs \coprod_{s \in S}A_s along with the function g:âˆsâˆˆSAsâ†’S g:\coprod_{s \in S}A_s \rightarrow S that sends every element in each As A_s to s s. This equivalence can be abstracted to categories by the following theorem.

[2, Proposition 1.1.7] Let ğ”¸ \mathbb{A} be a small category and X:ğ”¸opâ†’ğ’ğğ­ X: \mathbb{A}^{op} \rightarrow \mathbf{Set} a presheaf on ğ”¸ \mathbb{A}. Then there is an equivalence of categories:

[ğ”¸op,ğ’ğğ­]/Xâ‰ƒ[ğ”¼(X)op,ğ’ğğ­] [\mathbb{A}^{op}, \mathbf{Set}]/X \simeq [\mathbb{E}(X)^{op}, \mathbf{Set}].

I will give the functors required and leave the checking of the equivalence out, as it is pretty involved. The definitions of the functors require a proof to show that they are well defined (it needs to be shown that the natural transformations are indeed natural), however as this isnâ€™t too hard, we omit it. First, we define the following functor:

The functor (F,Î±)Ì‚ \widehat{(F,\alpha)} is defined as follows:

Where (F,Î±)Ì‚(f)(y)=(Ff)(y) \widehat{(F,\alpha)}(f)(y) = (Ff)(y). The natural transformation Î»Ì‚ \hat{\lambda} has components Î»Ì‚(A,x):Î±Aâˆ’1â†’Î²Aâˆ’1(x) \hat{\lambda}_{(A,x)}:\alpha_A^{-1} \rightarrow \beta_A^{-1}(x) with Î»Ì‚(A,x)(y)=Î»A(y) \hat{\lambda}_{(A,x)}(y) = \lambda_A(y). We now define a map in the other direction:

The functor Px:ğ”¸opâ†’ğ’ğğ­ P_x: \mathbb{A}^{op} \rightarrow \mathbf{Set} is defined as Px(A)=P(A,x) P_x(A) = P(A,x). This can then be made into a functor âˆxâˆˆX(âˆ’)Px:ğ”¸opâ†’ğ’ğğ­ \coprod_{x \in X(-)}P_x:\mathbb{A}^{op} \rightarrow \mathbf{Set}. The natural transformation PÌƒ \tilde{P} has components defined by the universal property of the coproduct. If yâˆˆPx(A) y \in P_x(A) then PÌƒA(y)=x \tilde{P}_A(y) = x. The natural transformation Î»Ìƒ \tilde{\lambda} has components with the following action on yâˆˆP(A,x) y \in P(A,x) - Î»ÌƒA(y)=Î»(A,x)(y) \tilde{\lambda}_A(y) = \lambda_{(A,x)}(y).

It is shown in the attached pdf that these functors give rise to an equivalence, hence proving the claim.

In conclusion, the category of elements is vital to proving that any presheaf is actually a colimit of a certain diagram. It also shows that slice categories of presheaf categories can be seen as a presheaf category themselves.

(1) T. Leinster, Basic category theory, 2014, 2016.

(2) T. Leinster, Higher operads, higher categories, 2013.

(3) J. Leslie, Category of elements, 2018
item.dc:creator: James Leslie

item.title: Yoneda, Yoneda, Yoneda
item.description:
Posted on April 23, 2018 by James Leslie

The Yoneda Lemma is one of the few â€˜theoremsâ€™ one learns in a first course on category theory and it is an invaluable tool.

Suppose we have a locally small category ğ’œ \mathcal{A}, then for any two objects A,B A, B there is a set of maps from A A to B B, denoted ğ’œ(A,B) \mathcal{A}(A,B). We can make this into a functor by forgetting about the domain. We define the following functor:

HB:ğ’œopâ†’ğ’ğğ­ H_B:\mathcal{A}^{op} \rightarrow \mathbf{Set},

such thatÂ Aâ†¦HB(A)=ğ’œ(A,B) A \mapsto H_B(A) = \mathcal{A}(A, B) andÂ (f:Aâ†’C)â†¦(HA(f):HA(C)â†’HA(A))(f:A \rightarrow C) \mapsto (H_A(f):H_A(C) \rightarrow H_A(A)). Given any map g:Câ†’A g:C \rightarrow A, (HA(f))(g)=gâˆ˜f:Aâ†’A (H_A(f))(g) = g \circ f:A \rightarrow A. We can go further however, by removing our choice of AA. We define a functor

Hâ‹…:ğ’œâ†’[ğ’œop,ğ’ğğ­]H_\cdot:\mathcal{A} \rightarrow [\mathcal{A}^\text{op}, \mathbf{Set}],

where Aâ†¦HA A \mapsto H_A and (f:Aâ†’B)â†¦(Hf:HAâ†’HB) (f:A \rightarrow B) \mapsto (H_f:H_A \rightarrow H_B), where Hf H_f is a natural transformation. For any Câˆˆğ’œ C \in \mathcal{A}, the C C component of Hf H_f is a function (Hf)C:HA(C)â†’HB(C) (H_f)_C:H_A(C) \rightarrow H_B(C) such that for any map g:Câ†’A g:C \rightarrow A, ((Hf)C)(g)=fâˆ˜g:Câ†’B ((H_f)_C)(g) = f \circ g:C \rightarrow B.

The functor Hâ‹… H_\cdot is known as the Yoneda embedding. It comes hand in hand with the Yoneda Lemma.

Yoneda lemma

Let ğ’œ\mathcal{A} be a locally small category. ThenÂ 

[ğ’œop,ğ’ğğ­](HA,X)â‰…X(A)[\mathcal{A}^\text{op}, \mathbf{Set}](H_A, X) \cong X(A),

naturally in Aâˆˆğ’œA \in \mathcal{A} and Xâˆˆ[ğ’œop,ğ’ğğ­] X \inÂ  [\mathcal{A}^\text{op}, \mathbf{Set}].

There are many discussions on the importance of Yoneda, however we shall skip over them and instead look at the Yoneda embedding. This functor can only really be called an embedding if it is both full and faithful. This is a trivial result of the Yoneda lemma, however it is not necessary to invoke the lemma and it can be proven without it.

Yoneda embedding is full and faithful

Let A,Aâ€²âˆˆğ’œ A, A' \in \mathcal{A}, and let Î±:HAâ†’HAâ€² \alpha:H_A \rightarrow H_{A'} be a natural transformation. We need to find a map f:Aâ†’Aâ€² f:A \rightarrow A' such that Î±=Hf \alpha = H_f. Looking at the A A component of Î± \alpha gives us a function

Î±A:HA(A)â†’HAâ€²(A)\alpha_A:H_A(A) \rightarrow H_{A'}(A).

We apply this to the identity map on A A to get a map Î±A(1A):Aâ†’Aâ€² \alpha_A(1_A):A \rightarrow A'. I claim that this is the required map. For notation, we shall call it f f. It is the case that Hf=Î± H_f = \alpha if and only if each component is equal, that is (Hf)B=Î±B (H_f)_B = \alpha_B for all objects Bâˆˆğ’œ B \in \mathcal{A}. Choosing an arbitrary Bâˆˆğ’œ B \in \mathcal{A}, as bothÂ Â (Hf)B (H_f)_B and Î±B \alpha_B are functions, they are equal if and only if they take the same values on the same inputs. Recall the domains and codomains of the functions:

(Hf)B,Î±B:HA(B)â†’HAâ€²(B)(H_f)_B, \alpha_B: H_A(B) \rightarrow H_{A'}(B).

Take an arbitrary map g:Bâ†’A g:B \rightarrow A. Then ((Hf)B)(g)=fâˆ˜g=Î±A(1A)âˆ˜g ((H_f)_B)(g) = f \circ g = \alpha_A(1_A) \circ g. We need to show that this is Î±B(g) \alpha_B(g). This follows from the naturality of Î± \alpha. Indeed, for naturality gives us the following commutative square:

These functions take the following on 1A 1_A:

This says that Î±B(g)=Î±A(1A)âˆ˜g \alpha_B(g) = \alpha_A(1_A) \circ g. This means Î±B \alpha_B and (Hf)B (H_f)_B are equal as functions, which means that Hf=Î± H_f = \alpha. which by our reasoning above shows that Î±=Hf \alpha = H_f, hence Hâ‹… H_\cdot is full.

For faithfulness, again fix A,Aâ€²âˆˆğ’œ A, A' \in \mathcal{A} and consider two natural transformations Hf,Hg:HAâ†’HAâ€² H_f, H_g: H_A \rightarrow H_A'. Supposing Hf=Hg H_f = H_g, we need to show that f=g f=g. As Hf=Hg H_f = H_g, (Hf)A=(Hg)A) (H_f)_A = (H_g)_A). These are both functions, so we apply them to 1A 1_A giving us fâˆ˜1A=gâˆ˜1A f \circ 1_A = g \circ 1_A, therefore f=g f = g, proving faithfulness.

Despite not explicitly using the Yoneda lemma, everything we have done is used in the proof of it. There is one more result that helps capture the idea behind the proof for Yoneda.

Yoneda embedding is injective on isomorphism classes

Suppose for two objects A,Bâˆˆğ’œ A, B \in \mathcal{A} that HAâ‰…HB H_A \cong H_{B}. This means that we have two natural isomorphisms:

Î±:HAâ†’HB,Î²:HBâ†’HA\alpha:H_A \rightarrow H_B, \qquad \beta:H_B \rightarrow H_A

which are inverses to each other. By reasoning from above, we a map Î±A(1A):Aâ†’B \alpha_A(1_A):A \rightarrow B and Î²B(1B):Bâ†’A \beta_B(1_B):B \rightarrow A. For notation, we shall call Î±A(1A)=f \alpha_A(1_A) = f and Î²B(1B)=g \beta_B(1_B) = g. Again from above, we see that Î±B(g)=Î±A(1A)âˆ˜g \alpha_B(g) = \alpha_A(1_A) \circ g. Substituting for g g gives that Î±B(Î²B(1B))=Î±A(1A)âˆ˜Î²B(1B) \alpha_B(\beta_B(1_B)) =Â \alpha_A(1_A) \circ \beta_B(1_B). As Î± \alpha and Î² \beta are inverses, their components are mutual inverses. This means Î±B(Î²B(1B))=1B \alpha_B(\beta_B(1_B)) = 1_B, so Î±A(1A)âˆ˜Î²B(1B)=1B \alpha_A(1_A) \circ \beta_B(1_B) = 1_B. A similar argument shows that Î²B(1B)âˆ˜Î±A(1A)=1A \beta_B(1_B) \circ \alpha_A(1_A) = 1_A, hence Î±A(1A) \alpha_A(1_A) and Î²B(1B) \beta_B(1_B) are isomorphisms. Therefore, Aâ‰…B A \cong B.

The results from this post are from Chapter 4 of Tom Leinsterâ€™s Basic Category Theory textbook, which can be found here.
item.dc:creator: James Leslie
